scripts.title: Your S&P 500 Fund Isn't as Diversified as You Think
scripts.hook: Five hundred companies. But seven of them control everything.

segments.audio: Five hundred companies. But seven of them control everything.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated number '500' appearing large and confident, then rapidly shrinking as '7' emerges dominant in center frame, dramatic scale shift effect, dark background with spotlight, attention-grabbing reveal, modern typography

segments.audio: The Magnificent Seven—Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet, NVIDIA, Meta, Tesla—make up thirty-five to forty percent of the entire S&P 500. When you buy VOO or SPY, you're getting a big helping of seven tech giants and small portions of everything else.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated pie chart with one massive slice (35-40%) glowing with tech company logos, remaining slice divided into many tiny slivers representing 493 other companies, dramatic size contrast, clean infographic style, company logos appearing as icons

segments.audio: Earlier this year, those seven dropped six-point-three percent. The other four-ninety-three? Barely moved—down just point-one percent. But if you owned the index, you felt almost the whole drop. The diversification didn't protect you.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated line chart: two lines starting together, then splitting dramatically—red line labeled 'Mag 7' plunging -6.3%, green line labeled 'Other 493' staying nearly flat at -0.1%, then combined S&P line following the red, visual proof of concentration risk

segments.audio: Here's how it works. The S&P 500 is market-cap weighted. Bigger companies get bigger slices. Apple is worth three trillion—it gets three hundred times more influence than a ten-billion-dollar utility. That's not a flaw. It's just how the index is built.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Medium shot of presenter with explanatory expression, hand gestures showing size contrast, brief overlay of Apple logo vs small utility icon with proportional bars, warm natural lighting, home office background, educational energy

segments.audio: Thirty years from retirement? Maybe that concentration is fine. Five years out? A big tech drop right before you need the money could hurt. It's about knowing what you own.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Split screen animation: left shows young person with long timeline, relaxed posture; right shows person closer to retirement with concerned expression - timeline bars above each showing different risk tolerance, clean visual comparison

segments.audio: Want to check your actual exposure? Link in bio. Let's look at what's really in your accounts.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Close-up of presenter with helpful genuine expression, smooth transition to end card 'Check Your Exposure - Link in Bio', modern gradient blue to purple, pie chart icon animation, educational branding

scripts.captions: On-screen: '7 companies = 35-40%' | 'Mag 7: -6.3% vs Others: -0.1%' | 'Know what you own'
scripts.filming_notes: The 500→7 visual hook is key. This challenges a common assumption without being alarmist. Educational tone throughout—this isn't about selling anything, it's about awareness. Don't bash index funds; explain how they work.
b_roll_prompts: Abstract visualization of stock market with seven massive glowing spheres dominating a field of tiny dots, scale contrast, dark cosmic background, modern motion graphics
Close-up of phone screen showing S&P 500 fund holdings with top 7 companies highlighted, over-shoulder shot, practical research moment
Tech company headquarters buildings montage: Apple Park, Microsoft campus, Amazon spheres - quick cuts showing the giants, corporate documentary style
Person reviewing retirement account on laptop with thoughtful expression, home office setting, warm afternoon light, planning moment
scripts.disclaimer: This content is for educational purposes only and does not constitute financial advice.

scripts.title: The 10-Minute Check Everyone's 401(k) Needs
scripts.hook: Most people can't name their top five holdings. Can you?

segments.audio: Most people can't name their top five holdings. Can you?
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated 401(k) statement document with large question mark floating over top holdings section, slight camera push-in, dramatic lighting on the unknown, curiosity-inducing visual, clean modern document design

segments.visual: Screen recording style: logging into account
segments.audio: Here's a ten-minute check that could change how you think about your retirement. Log into your account. Find your holdings. If you own an S&P 500 fund, look at the top ten. You'll probably see Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Alphabet, NVIDIA, Meta, Tesla.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Screen recording style animation: cursor clicking through retirement account interface, holdings list appearing, top companies highlighting one by one with logos appearing, clean modern investment platform UI, practical demonstration feel

segments.audio: Add up what those top holdings represent. If it's thirty percent or more, you're heavily concentrated in those names. And here's what many people miss—check your other accounts too. Brokerage? IRA? You might own the same seven stocks everywhere.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated percentage counter clicking upward: 10%, 20%, 30%, crossing threshold with warning pulse, then multiple account icons appearing showing same holdings duplicated across them, concentration multiplying visual, clean infographic

segments.audio: This isn't about panic. When those seven go up, your returns look great. But concentration works both ways. The same weighting that boosted you on the way up amplifies losses on the way down.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Medium shot of presenter with balanced calm expression, hand gesture showing two-way movement, warm natural lighting, home office setting, educational not alarmist energy, trustworthy advisor presence

segments.audio: Many employer plans offer options beyond basic S&P: equal-weight funds, international, bonds, target-date. Understanding your current allocation helps you decide if adjustments make sense for your timeline.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated menu of fund options appearing like app selections: 'Equal Weight', 'International', 'Bonds', 'Target Date' - each with simple icon, clean UI design, options without overwhelm, empowering choice visual

segments.audio: Spend ten minutes this week. Know what you own. Questions? Link in bio.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Close-up of presenter with encouraging expression, clock showing 10 minutes subtly visible, smooth transition to end card 'Know What You Own - Link in Bio', modern gradient green suggesting action, checkmark icon animation

scripts.captions: On-screen: 'Can you name your top 5?' | '30%+ = concentrated' | '10 minutes this week'
scripts.filming_notes: This is practical how-to content. The challenge question hook creates engagement. Walk through the steps clearly—viewers will do this themselves after watching. Non-judgmental throughout; this is about awareness, not selling.
b_roll_prompts: Hands typing login credentials on laptop, retirement account login screen visible, practical action shot
Close-up of person's surprised expression while reviewing account, discovery moment, natural lighting
Multiple device screens showing different accounts with overlapping holdings highlighted, concentration across platforms visual
Person writing notes while reviewing investments, organized planning, warm home office setting

scripts.title: Equal-Weight vs Market-Cap: Which Bet Are You Making?
scripts.hook: There are two versions of the S&P 500. Most people only know one.

segments.visual: Two doors appearing: VOO/SPY vs RSP
segments.audio: There are two versions of the S&P 500. Most people only know one.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Two doors appearing side by side, left labeled 'VOO/SPY' with market-cap symbol, right labeled 'RSP' with equal bars symbol, slight mystery lighting, choice visualization, dramatic reveal setup, clean modern design

segments.audio: Most index funds are market-cap weighted. Bigger companies get bigger slices. Apple is worth three trillion, a small company worth ten billion. Apple gets three hundred times more influence in your fund.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Animated pie chart with Apple slice massive (labeled $3T), tiny slice for small company (labeled $10B), extreme size contrast, clean visual showing the 300x difference, modern financial visualization, educational infographic style

segments.audio: Equal-weight funds like RSP work differently. Every company—from Apple to the smallest—gets roughly the same slice. The five-hundredth company matters just as much as the first.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Contrasting pie chart where all 500 slices are equal size, uniform distribution, democratic visual, then zoom showing Apple and small company with same allocation, satisfying equality visual, clean balanced design

segments.audio: The tradeoff? When mega-caps surge, equal-weight lags behind. When mega-caps stumble, equal-weight holds up better. Neither is right or wrong—they're different bets on what happens next.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Split scenario animation: top shows 'Mega-caps UP' with market-cap winning, bottom shows 'Mega-caps DOWN' with equal-weight winning, see-saw visual showing inverse relationship, clean comparison infographic, educational not promotional

segments.audio: If you believe the biggest keep getting bigger, market-cap rewards that. If you think smaller companies might catch up, equal-weight spreads the risk. It's about what you believe, not what's 'better.'
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Medium shot of presenter with thoughtful balanced expression, hands showing two options gesture, warm natural lighting, home office background, no-sales-pitch energy, genuinely educational stance

segments.audio: Curious which approach fits your situation? Link in bio. Let's compare the options together.
segments.ai_visual_prompt: Close-up of presenter with helpful inviting expression, smooth transition to end card 'Compare Your Options - Link in Bio', modern gradient showing two colors merging, choice icon animation, decision-support branding

scripts.captions: On-screen: 'Market-cap = Big companies dominate' | 'Equal-weight = Everyone equal' | 'Different bets, not better/worse'
scripts.filming_notes: This explains a concept most retail investors don't know exists. Keep it neutral—not pushing either approach. The 'different bets' framing is key; avoid implying one is superior. Viewers should leave informed, not sold.
